doc.abstracts: Money markets trade in debt--unsecured overnight loans, commercial bills, treasury bills, and repurchase agreements--of less than a year to maturity. To work efficiently, these basic building blocks in the development of capital markets need liquidity, multilateral trading, and a range of participants. This Note describes the features of a liquid and efficient money market and the benefits it brings to banks, savers, borrowers, other financial markets, the government, and the central bank. Efficient money markets need the right incentives for participation and an adequate infrastructure for fast, safe, and easy transactions. This Note outlines the important steps in creating the right incentive structure. It identifies the key parts of infrastructure for an interbank, a primary bill, and a secondary bill market, and the components of the infrastructure specific to creating primary and secondary bill markets. A separate box in the Note provides a general picture of sequencing in the development of a money market.
